critique: This executive order deals with the designation of economically less developed countries for tax purposes, specifically related to the Interest Equalization Tax Act. It removes certain countries from the list of less developed countries and defines the 'Sino-Soviet bloc.' It also includes provisions for prior commitments to acquire stock or debt obligations. The order delegates authority to the Secretary of the Treasury to issue regulations. It does not directly address immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. It has some implications for economic regulation and international trade. It is difficult to assess its ideological tilt without more context, but it seems primarily technical. It does not appear to significantly expand executive power or shift the balance of federalism.
